title: Remove scons support
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
The files and code needed to support SCons builds is removed.

@cournape David, can you check the code removal in the distutils functions? It may be possible the remove numpy/distutils/numpy_distribution.py as well, but that wasn't clear to me. Also, can numpy/core/setup_common.py now be merged with the setup.py file?

title: Switch to separate compilation by default
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/njsmith', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/609896?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'njsmith', 'type': u'User', 'id': 609896, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/followers'}
body:
Let's make 1.8 use separate compilation by default, with an eye towards eventually phasing out the "one big blob" style of compilation (though for now we will certainly continue to support both).

Todo:
* Make the code that checks for NPY_SEPARATE_COMPILATION instead check for NPY_ALL_IN_ONE_COMPILATION (or something like that), and flip the default
* Update the .travis.yml so that it runs some tests with this new variable set instead of the current NPY_SEPARATE_COMPILATION tests
* Make sure to document the new variable somewhere so in case anyone runs into problems caused by this, they have some hope of reverting to the old behaviour without having to work it out from first principles.

title: Update numpy/core/code_generators/ufunc_docstrings.py
Nonarray assignment regression for boolean indexing and 1d unsafe casting
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/seberg', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/61977?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'seberg', 'type': u'User', 'id': 61977, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/followers'}
body:
There are two commits here, the first one is a regression in 1.7. and probably should be backported, the second one gives a special case the same behaviour as (most?) other code branches for index assignments has:

 1. Fix a regression that a = np.array([1,2]), b = np.array([True, True]) then a[b] = np.nan fails (but a[b] = np.array(np.nan) does not as it never did)
 2. Make 1d special case with r = np.array([0,1]), a[r] = 12.5 use unsafe casting as the rest of the assignments normally use, but still keep make a[r] = np.nan fail as before.

title: Nonarray assignment regression for boolean indexing and 1d unsafe casting
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/seberg', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/61977?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'seberg', 'type': u'User', 'id': 61977, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/followers'}
body:
There are two commits here, and only the first one is probably interesting (the other one is not a regression):

 1. Fix a regression that `a = np.array([1,2])`, `b = np.array([True, True])` then `a[b] = np.nan` fails (but `a[b] = np.array(np.nan)` does not as it never did)
 2. Make 1d special case with `r = np.array([0,1])`, `a[r] = 12.5` use *unsafe* casting as the rest of the assignments normally use, but still keep make `a[r] = np.nan` fail as before.

I just wanted to point out 2... point 1. is the thing that caused the gh-2870 behaviour change.

**Careful:** I did this pull request against 1.7. because there seem so many uncommited changes for `mapping.c` out there that this would just make things harder to merge if done at this time...

title: BUG: raise ValueError for nanarg(min|max) for all nan along axis
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/seberg', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/61977?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'seberg', 'type': u'User', 'id': 61977, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/followers'}
body:
The assignment of nan to the non-floating result of these function
always caused a ValueError. This adds a more specific error and removes
relying on the assignment failing.

See also gh-2870

title: assigning with mask of float32 array elements fails for int argument
body:
Hello,

The following code raises TypeError: array cannot be safely cast to required type

	a = np.zeros(1, dtype=np.int)
	b = np.zeros(1, dtype=np.float32)
	mask = np.array([True], dtype=np.bool)
	b[mask] = a[:]

Notice, that if b is of type np.float64, this code passes:

	a = np.zeros(1, dtype=np.int)
	b = np.zeros(1, dtype=np.float64)
	mask = np.array([True], dtype=np.bool)
	b[mask] = a[:]
	print('ok')

title: np.ndindex() is now failing
body:
On master and maintenance/1.7.x the following code is now failing: 

np.ndindex()

This has been traced to the code added in #444 (ctors.c:2082-2086) and #2815 (ctors.c:2083-2087) which does what seems to be an unnecessary but explicit check to invalidate array scalars in the array interface. 

This can be fixed by removing that check.

title: np.linalg.svd fails to perform decomposition on vector
body:
Code to reproduce:

A = np.random.normal(size=10)  
decomp = np.linalg.svd

There are several reasons why not allowing an SVD on a vector are a very bad idea:

-- The SVD is properly mathematically defined for any real-valued matrix with m >= 1 columns and n >= 1 rows.  As such, it is a bit silly to not provide this functionality 

-- pinv calls SVD and a pseudoinverse is also completely mathematically valid for a vector (or a scalar!).

-- The real reason: In many greedy algorithms (such as forward subset selection, orthogonal matching pursuit, etc.), you'd have to modify the code on the first step (which is very inelegant) in which you would be computing the pseudoinverse of an n by 1 matrix (i.e., n-dimensional vector).  Of course it's easy to code the corresponding mathematical operator w/ dot products and what not, but you shouldn't have to, and in fact you don't in R.  In short, I think this should be fixed.

- Adam

body:
The test code

```
import numpy
indices = numpy.array([], 'i8')
x = numpy.array([], 'f8')
numpy.add.reduceat(x, indices)
```

works in numpy 1.4, but raises an error in 1.8. I've got a patch for this, will make a pull request for it.

title: Deprecate non integer function arguments
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/seberg', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/61977?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'seberg', 'type': u'User', 'id': 61977, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/followers'}
body:
These changes make numpy generally use the index machinery for converting
of integers (almost) everywhere, and deprecates the use of floating point
numbers.

This has many changes, so here is an overview:
  1. Deprecate use of booleans, floats or high dimensional arrays
     integers, where the high dimensional array part is due to
  2. deprecating array.__index__() if array.ndim != 0
  3. No attempt is made at giving a function specific meaningful
     DeprecationWarning. IE. indexing or np.reshape all give the same
     warnings. For the case of raised DeprecationWarnings, no attempt
     is made to show it. Indexing will raise an Index error instead
     (so you get the error you would get when the deprecation process is
     done in these cases)
  4. Because it is changed so deep down (and hard to pull apart in indexing)
     espeacially there it is possible to get multiple warnings for one
     command. `arr[0.0,:]` (for a 2-d array) will even give two warnings.
  5. I tried around a bit what is fastest, the cases where PyIntAsInt*
     were not used may have been a bit faster. Using index is actually
     much faster for arrays and array scalars.
  6. This fixes some occurances where integer division was not yet used
     and errors were created in Py3k

--

The biggest discussion maybe should be about point 3. Should we attempt to control the number of warnings and try to raise the original `DeprecationWarning` instead of basically giving the error that would occur after the deprecation is finished? The other thing would be maybe point 2, but honestly this is such an esoteric thing that I cannot believe anyone relies on it in itself, and other then that it leads to deprecating the use `array([4])` for an integer in indexing and with this inside numpy.

title: Fix headers
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
This does some maintenance work on the numpy headers. The details are in the commit comments, but generally some rearrangement is done, outdated comments removed, hard tab removal, and such. There are some new unprefixed macros added to the noprefix.h file just in case, and npy_config is fixed so that the macros used are defined and duplicate code removed.

There are some files including config.h directly that also need fixing, but that is deferred to a later PR.

title: BUG: Replace unprefixed SIZEOF_* macros with prefixed versions.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/charris', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/77272?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'charris', 'type': u'User', 'id': 77272, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/charris/followers'}
body:
The sources don't define NPY_NO_PREFIX and consequently none of the
unprefixed macros are defined. Using them can lead to some unexpected
results.

@certik, this complimemts the seberg fix and should be backported after it if you do the backport. Or you could put the two together into one PR.

title: BUG: Fix byteswapping for complex scalars
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/seberg', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/61977?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'seberg', 'type': u'User', 'id': 61977, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/followers'}
body:
During a cleanup, the fast paths were invalidated because SIZEOF_LONGDOUBLE
was not defined anymore and needs to be replaced with NPY_SIZEOF_LONGDOUBLE.
The other SIZEOF macros still existed however so only complex long double
broke because it switched to the already broken fast path.

This commit fixes the fast path, and replaces all SIZEOF_ macros within
arraytypes.c.src with their corresponding NPY_SIZEOF_ macros.

---

This probably fixes issue gh-411 though that still needs checking. Note that there are still many occurrences where these macros need to be replaced. Also I noticed that the `noprefix.h` does not include `SIZEOF_COMPLEX_*`.

title: median calls mean, apparently for no good reason. Complexity of algorithm is wrong.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cottrell/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cottrell/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cottrell/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cottrell', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cottrell/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/cottrell', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cottrell/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/223276?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cottrell/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cottrell/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cottrell/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'cottrell', 'type': u'User', 'id': 223276, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cottrell/followers'}
body:
numpy.median is defined in numpy/libs/function_base.py. At the very last step "mean" is called. I think this can be replaced by something (i.e. len/2 ) that I'm guessing will be O(1) rather than O(n).

    # Use mean in odd and even case to coerce data type
    # and check, use out array.
    return mean(sorted[indexer], axis=axis, out=out)

I would almost consider this a bug since the complexity of the algorithm is completely wrong.

title: Fixed choice docstring, wrong default size
body: Commit acf7421128b9d974d5153759650b7aaee3c2efec introduced a change in the handling of the `size` argument but the docstring wasn't updated accordingly. This commit fixes the issue.

title: BUG: Fix CheckStrides and strides setter checks for available memory
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/seberg', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/61977?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'seberg', 'type': u'User', 'id': 61977, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/followers'}
body:
This changes the logic of PyArray_CheckStrides to really check the
full extent the new array will have. It also changes the stride
setting to calculate the full real extent of the underlying array
without assuming (usually correctly) that the strides of the base
array are regular.

Add some tests for cases that previously failed.
This "closes Issue gh-2503"

---

I don't love duplicating that code, but I did not know a great alternative, this will break abuses that explicitly created invalid arrays obviously.

title: If Python warnings module is used to catch RuntimeWarning, numpy.log raises TypeError on issubclass()
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/emprice/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/emprice/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/emprice/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/emprice', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/emprice/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/emprice', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/emprice/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3172578?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/emprice/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/emprice/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/emprice/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'emprice', 'type': u'User', 'id': 3172578, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/emprice/followers'}
body:
If the Python `warnings` module is used to catch and handle `RuntimeWarning` as an error, `numpy.log(0.)` will raise a `TypeError` on `issubclass()` (not called by the user). For example (Python prompt):

    >>> import numpy
    >>> import warnings
    >>> numpy.log(0.)
    __main__:1: RuntimeWarning: divide by zero encountered in log
    -inf
    >>> warnings.simplefilter("error", "RuntimeWarning")
    >>> try
    ...    numpy.log(0.)
    ...except RuntimeWarning:
    ...    pass
    ...
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "<stdin>", line 2, in <module>
    TypeError: issubclass() arg 2 must be a class or tuple of classes

title: uint64 causing errors when used to address byte position in a large binary file
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Erdaron/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Erdaron/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Erdaron/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Erdaron', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Erdaron/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/Erdaron', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Erdaron/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3165054?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Erdaron/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Erdaron/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Erdaron/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'Erdaron', 'type': u'User', 'id': 3165054, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Erdaron/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20numpy.core', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: numpy.core'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Defect', 'color': u'444444', 'name': u'Defect'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/priority:%20normal', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'priority: normal'}]
body:
I am working with large binary files (several gigabytes each), and I need to be able to address specific bytes in those files. So I keep addresses of data within these files using 64-bit integers, specifically numpy types int64 and uint64. However, I noticed that the unsigned version is giving an error:

>>> ids1 = np.fromfile('TR_45_3 ch 0 cluster 1.txt', dtype = np.uint64, sep = ' ')
>>> ids1[-1]
4999998
>>> tes4530.goto(ids1[-1])

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<pyshell#55>", line 1, in <module>
    tes4530.goto(ids1[-1])
  File "xxx\tes_utility.py", line 32, in goto
    self.f.seek(newpos * 2 * self.rec_len)
OverflowError: Python int too large to convert to C long  

If record addresses are stored using the signed version (numpy.int64), no such error occurs.

tes4530 above is an instance of a class I wrote to help accessing these files. Relevant code is reproduced below:

class TESstream1:
    #Objects of this class allow loading and searching data from a
    # a binary file containing single-channel data
    def __init__(self, fname, rec_len = 256, outtype = np.float32):
        #rec_len - number of data points per record
        #outtype - number type used in the outputs
        self.records = os.path.getsize(fname) / (2 * rec_len)
        self.f = open(fname, 'rb')
        self.rec_len = rec_len
        self.fname = fname
        self.outtype = outtype
        self.x = 2 ** 15 #offset to compensate for data being unsigned
    def goto(self, newpos):
        #go to the beginning of the record specified by newpos)
        self.f.seek(newpos * 2 * self.rec_len) 
    def read(self, Nrec = 1):
        #returns the next Nrec records
        d = np.fromfile(self.f, dtype = np.uint16, count = Nrec * self.rec_len)
        if self.outtype != np.uint16:
            d = np.array(d, dtype = self.outtype)
        return np.reshape(d, (Nrec, self.rec_len)) - self.x

In particular, errors begin to arise when the record address is 4194304 or higher (this translates to byte address 2^31 - 256 data points per record, 2 bytes per data point).

Using the signed version (numpy.int64) does not raise any errors, and it appears that the correct records are being addressed (access does not appear to reset to the beginning of file or read random bits, for example).

I am using Python 2.7.2 64-bit, numpy numpy 1.6.1 64-bit (from Christoph Gohlke's repository), running on Windows 7 x64.

there were some references to numpy.scipy.org, which now 404s, so I changed them to point to www.numpy.org.

These are the references left:

numpy/core/include/numpy/ndarraytypes.h: * http://numpy.scipy.org/array_interface.shtml for the full

Do you also want a PR for 1.7 branch or on master is ok? given propose a wrong homepage is a bad advertize, I'm inclined to say it should be fixed before 1.7 too.

Cheers,
Sandro

title: FFT2 issue
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Gr8Scott/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Gr8Scott/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Gr8Scott/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Gr8Scott', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Gr8Scott/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/Gr8Scott', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Gr8Scott/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/3146323?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Gr8Scott/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Gr8Scott/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Gr8Scott/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'Gr8Scott', 'type': u'User', 'id': 3146323, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Gr8Scott/followers'}
body:
I have run into a problem with fft2.

I have noticed difficulties getting the symmetry that should exist after a fft2: with a size (M,N) image and indexes starting at 0, F(u,v) = F(M-1-u, N-1-v)

Rather than F(0,0) being equal to F(M-1, N-1), F(1,1) is equal to F(M-1, N-1), and the entire first row & column does not line up with the rest.

I used a 4x4 image as an extreme case so that I could print out the results of the fft2:
![__2ExtremeCase](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/3146323/35018/03175d78-517b-11e2-99c1-836c857d6e4b.jpg)
^ it's tiny, and I used the python image library to load it and then numpy.asarray() to make it into an array for the fft2().  I saved the code into a py file, and each time I want to run it, I drag the image onto the py file.  Here are it's contents:

import sys
import numpy
from PIL import Image

imgOrig = Image.open(sys.argv[1])
temp = numpy.asarray(imgOrig )
fft = numpy.fft.fft2(temp)
print(fft)
input("Press Enter to quit")


Finally, here is the output.
![Result](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/3146323/35021/542cebc8-517c-11e2-9bba-a571b7c6949d.jpg)


And, I moved the rows over manually in GIMP since it was hard to see the asymmetry/symmetry when it wrapped:
![Result2](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/3146323/35023/da52c2e0-517c-11e2-8e50-6d8a3d547b3d.jpg)

title: FIX: remove a spurious check in get_cast_transfer_function
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/njsmith', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/609896?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'njsmith', 'type': u'User', 'id': 609896, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/followers'}
body:
At least, I hope it's spurious. Certainly it's creating a spurious
error message, is unexpected by callers (one of whom specifically
makes the *opposite* check before calling get_cast_transfer_function),
and even if it is a useful check for some reason I can't see, it
certainly doesn't belong in this function (which is otherwise just
taking care of byte-swapping and alignment issues and doesn't know
anything about dtypes). And worst case, we'll have turned an exception
into a crash; even if I'm wrong, this shouldn't cause any code to go
from working to not working, just from broken to slightly-more-broken.

Test and original diagnosis by @cgohlke.

Fixes gh-2798.

title: DOC: Thoroughly document datetime issues
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/certik', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/20568?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'certik', 'type': u'User', 'id': 20568, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/followers'}
body:
After understanding the issues with datetime (see gh-568), I have documented my
understanding as comments in the code, so that the next time there are problems
with datetime on some platform, one can quickly figure out what is going on
from the code + comments.

title: FIX: Use the NPY_TIME_T macro everywhere
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/certik', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/20568?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'certik', 'type': u'User', 'id': 20568, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/followers'}
body:
Previously, two (critical) parts of the code used `time_t` instead of
`NPY_TIME_T`. Due to the fact, that most of the time `NPY_TIME_T` was equal to
`time_t`, this bug didn't show up. But in mingw, `NPY_TIME_T` is actually equal
to `__time64_t` and then this causes 64 bit integers to be cast into 32 bit
integers (thus becoming negative), which causes localtime() to fail in mingw.

Fixes gh-568.

title: FIX: Use the NPY_TIME_T macro everywhere
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/certik', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/20568?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'certik', 'type': u'User', 'id': 20568, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/followers'}
body:
Previously, two (critical) parts of the code used `time_t` instead of
`NPY_TIME_T`. Due to the fact, that most of the time `NPY_TIME_T` was equal to
`time_t`, this bug didn't show up. But in mingw, `NPY_TIME_T` is actually equal
to `__time64_t` and then this causes 64 bit integers to be cast into 32 bit
integers (thus becoming negative), which causes localtime() to fail in mingw.

Fixes gh-568.

title: fftfreq dosent work with 64bit-ints
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Tillsten/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Tillsten/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Tillsten/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Tillsten', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Tillsten/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/Tillsten', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Tillsten/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/189880?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Tillsten/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Tillsten/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Tillsten/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'Tillsten', 'type': u'User', 'id': 189880, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/Tillsten/followers'}
body:
On a 64bit system the following dosen't work:

    fftfreq(2L)

Casting to python int first works:

    fftfreq(int(2L))

title: Regression: numpy.ndindex() fail in NumPy 1.7 branch and in master
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/nouiz/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/nouiz/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/nouiz/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/nouiz', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/nouiz/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/nouiz', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/nouiz/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/180987?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/nouiz/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/nouiz/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/nouiz/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'nouiz', 'type': u'User', 'id': 180987, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/nouiz/followers'}
body:
In NumPy 1.7, I have this error:

>>> numpy.ndindex()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/numpy/lib/index_tricks.py", line 536, in __init__
    x = as_strided(_nx.zeros(1), shape=shape, strides=_nx.zeros_like(shape))
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/numpy/lib/stride_tricks.py", line 28, in as_strided
    return np.asarray(DummyArray(interface, base=x))
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/numpy/core/numeric.py", line 324, in asarray
    return array(a, dtype, copy=False, order=order)
ValueError: __array_interface__ shape must be at least size 1


In NumPy 1.6.1, I have this:

>>> numpy.ndindex()
<numpy.lib.index_tricks.ndindex object at 0x7f9015364750>
>>>numpy.ndindex().next()
()

This make this Theano test fail:

nosetests -s --pdb --pdb-failure theano/tensor/signal/tests/test_downsample.py:TestDownsampleFactorMax.test_max_pool_2d_2D

title: histogramdd fails on data points that are close to rightmost bin edge
body:
My numpy  version is 1.6.1-6 on ubuntu 12.04 64-bit with python 2.7.3.

I want to create histograms with the function histogramdd.
When I have data points that are very close to the rightmost bin-edge, they will land in the wrong bin, that is, in the second-to-right bin, instead of the rightmost bin!

Here is some code to reproduce this behavior:
```python
>>> import numpy as np
>>> x = np.random.randint(0,3,100)
>>> edges = [[-0.5, 0.5, 1.5, 2+1e-7]]
>>> np.histogramdd(x,edges)
(array([ 33.,  67.,   0.]),
 [array([-0.5      ,  0.5      ,  1.5      ,  2.0000001])])
```
The last bin is empty and all data points with value 2 are in the second bin.
Note that the last bin edge is very close to 2 but not exactly 2!
This doesn't happen using the 1d function:
```python
>>> np.histogram(x,edges[0])
(array([33, 37, 30]), array([-0.5      ,  0.5      ,  1.5      ,  2.0000001]))
```

The problem seems to be in line 347 of function_base.py (in my version):
```python
    for i in arange(D):
        Ncount[i] = digitize(sample[:,i], edges[i])
```

...together with the following code (line 356ff), where all the data points that fall on the rightmost edge are shifted one bin to the left:
```python
        if not np.isinf(mindiff):
            decimal = int(-log10(mindiff)) + 6
            # Find which points are on the rightmost edge.
            on_edge = where(around(sample[:,i], decimal) == around(edges[i][-1],
                                                                   decimal))[0]
```

What happens is that the data points that are 2 fall into the 3rd bin, because they are smaller then the last edge 2.0000001. The 'digitize' function would put all points that were exactly 2.0000001  into an outlier bin! Then, in order to correct for the edge-points that were classified as outliers, these are shifted one bin to the left. However, to find them the data points and edges are rounded to 'decimal' precision, which has not be done in the first 'digitize' operation. So this time all the 2s are thought to be on the edge and shifted to the 2nd bin, although they were already in the correct bin!

I recommend to change line 347 to round the edges already here to 'decimal' precision:
```python
    for i in arange(D):
        if not np.isinf(mindiff):
            decimal = int(-log10(mindiff)) + 6
            Ncount[i] = digitize(sample[:,i], around(edges[i], decimal))
        else:
            Ncount[i] = digitize(sample[:,i], edges[i])
```


I hope I could make clear what the problem is. For now I found the error and can design my bin-edges to be far enough away or exactly at the maximum of the data. But it would be nice if this could be fixed in future releases.

I don't really know how to debug the issue but here is the information I collected from the last segfault. I can provide more info if necessary, just need to be pointed to some instructions.

body:
This switches us back to the behaviour seen in numpy 1.6 and earlier,
which it turns out that scikit-learn (and probably others) relied on.

they are correct to relative tolerance 1e-15.

title: FIX: Fixes the segfault in PyArray_FromScalar
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/certik', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/20568?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'certik', 'type': u'User', 'id': 20568, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/followers'}
body:
The problem was that PyArray_NewFromDescr() steals a reference to typecode and
so any further usage of it is undefined. Apparently this bug only appeared in
debug version of Python 3.2. The fix is to simply INCREF typecode and then
carefully DECREF it at each possible exit from the function.

Fixes gh-2738.

title: Fix unicode tests for flexible string representation on Python 3.3

body:
The master branch version had diverged from the release branch.  This
brings them back into sync, adds a mention that Python 2.4 - 2.5 support
has been dropped, corrects spelling errors, does some reformatting, and
removes trailing whitespace.

@certik, this should be backported to 1.7.0.

title: FIX: Fixes the segfault in PyArray_FromScalar
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/certik', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/20568?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'certik', 'type': u'User', 'id': 20568, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/followers'}
body:
The problem was that PyArray_NewFromDescr() steals a reference to typecode and
so any further usage of it is undefined. Apparently this bug only appeared in
debug version of Python 3.2. The fix is to simply INCREF typecode and then
carefully DECREF it at each possible exit from the function.

Fixes gh-2738.

title: BUG: internal call fix in random.choice
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/certik', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/20568?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'certik', 'type': u'User', 'id': 20568, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/certik/followers'}
body:
An random.random call from within mtrand was done by a call to
np.random.random instead of inside the class. This can possibly lead
to non-deterministic results after seeding.

Conflicts:

	numpy/random/mtrand/mtrand.c
	numpy/random/mtrand/mtrand.pyx

title: ENH: Deprecation for invalid fancy index sequences.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dwf/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dwf/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dwf/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dwf', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dwf/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/dwf', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dwf/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/60206?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dwf/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dwf/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dwf/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'dwf', 'type': u'User', 'id': 60206, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dwf/followers'}
body:
This raises a `DeprecationWarning` when a non-array fancy index sequence a) is not a sequence of booleans b) contains something not castable to npy_intp (i.e. a float). The way it gets there is a bit shaky, but it works. I'd like to solicit feedback on the best way to do this before merging.

What this does do, so far, is add tests, and also identify where the changes need to be made. A better implementation of `_verify_index` is definitely possible and probably preferable.

title: BUG: internal call fix in random.choice
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/seberg', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/61977?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'seberg', 'type': u'User', 'id': 61977, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/followers'}
body:
An random.random call from within mtrand was done by a call to np.random.random instead of inside the class. This can possibly lead to non-deterministic results after seeding.

Sorry that I noticed this only after mtrand was recreated already for this function... @njsmith this is the extremely simple fix, I guess @certik should put this into 1.7. as well? I included a regression test that failed before and double checked that there is no further occurrence of this at the time.

title: Fix for ufuncs with built in input operands and custom output operands
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jayvius/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jayvius/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jayvius/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jayvius', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jayvius/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/jayvius', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jayvius/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1474463?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jayvius/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jayvius/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jayvius/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'jayvius', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1474463, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jayvius/followers'}
body: This pull request modifies find_userloop() and linear_search_userloop_type_resolver() so that they search for ufunc functions by trying to find a match for all operands, not just input operands. This resolves the issue where a ufunc is written that takes built in types as input and a custom type as output.

title: in place fancy indexing for ufuncs
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jayvius/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jayvius/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jayvius/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jayvius', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jayvius/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/jayvius', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jayvius/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1474463?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jayvius/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jayvius/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jayvius/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'jayvius', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1474463, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/jayvius/followers'}
body:
Currently when doing something like a[idx] += 1 where idx is a fancy index, and the fancy index lists an element more than once, the increment is performed on each element's original value instead of accumulating the increments. This is because the first operand is buffered, and the ufunc operates on the buffered operand. 

This pull request adds a new method called 'at' to ufunc object for in place fancy indexing with no buffering.  This allows a ufunc operation to be performed on an element more than once, with the result of each operation being stored in place before the next operation is performed. This is equivalent to doing a[idx] += b with no buffering for operand 'a'. For example:

a = np.array([0,1,2,3])
\# second element is incremented twice
np.add.at(a, [0,1,1], 1)
a
\>>> array([1, 3, 2, 3)]

The 'at' method also supports slicing. For example:

a = np.array([0,1,2,3])
np.add.at(a, (slice(None),), 1)
a
\>>> array([1, 2, 3, 4)]

A more complicated example:

a = np.arange(27).reshape(3,3,3)
b = np.array([100,200,300])
np.add.at(a, (slice(None), slice(None), [1,2,1]), b)
a
\>>> array([[[0,401,202], 
      [3,404,205], 
      [6,407,208]],
     [[9, 410,211],  
      [12,413,214], 
      [15,416,217]],
     [[18,419,220],
      [21,422,223],
      [24,425,226]]])

The 'at' method can be used with all ufuncs, including unary ufuncs:

a = np.array([0, 1, 2, 3])
np.negative.at(a, [0,1])
a
\>>> array([0, -1, 2, 3])

title: Deprecate non-integer axes
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/seberg', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/61977?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'seberg', 'type': u'User', 'id': 61977, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/followers'}
body:
I remembered this because of the discussion about deprecating non-inter (non `__index__`) indices. I think similar should be done for the axes argument to numpy functions. Right now most/all of the C backed functions silently allow a non-integer axis argument (not as bad as indexing that even allows strings...), while most python functions at some point do something like `arr.shape[axes]` that fails.

Its a smaller thing then the indexing, but I think it should be handled just the same as indexing with scalars.

title: Deprecate non-integer scalar indices and slice parameters
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dwf/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dwf/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dwf/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dwf', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dwf/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/dwf', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dwf/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/60206?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dwf/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dwf/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dwf/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'dwf', 'type': u'User', 'id': 60206, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/dwf/followers'}
body:
Fixes #2810. Does not address non-integers in list/fancy indices, i.e. #2811.

The relevant (scalar) indexing code basically breaks down into three code paths:

* Single scalar indices
* Indexing an n-dimensional array with a tuple of n scalars
* Everything else

This adds a DeprecationWarning in the right place in each of them. Since the warning string is the same, it'll only trigger once if it's been triggered anywhere.

For slices, this adds checks inside `slice_GetIndices`, which should probably be removed once slicing with floats becomes an error in favor of `PySlice_GetIndicesEx`.

title: When indexing numpy arrays, treat lists and array input the same way
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/njsmith', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/609896?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'njsmith', 'type': u'User', 'id': 609896, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/followers'}
body:
Right now, if you use a Python list object to index an ndarray, then it is silently hard-cast to integer (see also gh-2810):

```
a = np.arange(3)
# This is the same as a[[1, 2]]
a[[1.5, 2.5]]
# This is the same as a[[0, 0, 0]] (!!!)
a[[False, False, False]]
```

The behaviour for floating point input is confusing, dangerous, and inconsistent with how ndarray input is handled: `a[np.array([1.5, 2.5])]` is an error.

The behaviour for boolean input is even *more* confusing and dangerous. Srsly wtf? Obviously this gives entirely different results than `a[np.array([False, False, False])]`.

We want to make it so that if `L` is a list object, then `a[L]` and `a[np.array(L)]` produce the same result. But, the boolean handling makes this a bit trickier to fix than gh-2810, though, because there we're just adding an error; here we're converting one non-error into a different non-error, so there's more danger of silently breaking user code.

Plan:
* Step 1 (as soon as possible): when we get a list as input to indexing, run the dtype auto-detection code, and if it returns a non-integer dtype, then produce a FutureWarning (not a DeprecationWarning).
* Step 2 (a release or two later): when we get a list as input to indexing, just convert it to an ndarray using the equivalent of `np.asarray`, and then use the ndarray input path. EXCEPT, if the resulting ndarray has a boolean type, produce an error
* Step 3 (a release or two later): Remove the error on boolean lists, so that they too act like ndarray input.

title: Deprecate the use of non-integer/non-boolean indexes for arrays
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/njsmith', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/609896?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'njsmith', 'type': u'User', 'id': 609896, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/njsmith/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20numpy.core', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: numpy.core'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Easy%20Fix', 'color': u'02e10c', 'name': u'Easy Fix'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Enhancement', 'color': u'e102d8', 'name': u'Enhancement'}]
body:
Currently, we have:

```
a = np.arange(10)
# error, index must be integer or boolean
a[np.array([1.5])]
# but this is silently treated like a[1]
a[1.5]
```

Silently truncating floating point numbers like this is both risky and inconsistent with how we handle indexes which are arrays.

Step 1 (as soon as possible): make the indexing code issue a deprecation warning whenever we cast a non-integer/non-boolean scalar.

Step 2 (a relase or two later): replace this warning with an error.

title: BUG: site.cfg.example should describe the actual BLAS detection process
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bfroehle/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bfroehle/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bfroehle/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bfroehle', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bfroehle/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/bfroehle', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bfroehle/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/204333?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bfroehle/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bfroehle/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bfroehle/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'bfroehle', 'type': u'User', 'id': 204333, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bfroehle/followers'}
body:
Instead of gh-2751 (`ENH: Respect blas_opt and lapack_opt groups in site.cfg`), this pull request updates `site.cfg.example` to describe the actual detection process for the BLAS & LAPACK libraries.

I don't expect that this pull request will be well received, but it should be useful for discussion as I believe it documents the actual state of affairs in the `site.cfg` file.

Primary changes:
* Remove deprecation of `[atlas]` section.
* Highlight need to "zero-out" certain sections to avoid them in the autodetection process.
* Point out that `_dotblas` won't be built if using the `[blas]` section.

I haven't thoroughly proofread this. Send any corrections my way and I'll happily update the pull request.

title: Docstring for numpy.load() incorrectly describes "file-like object" requirements.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/abingham/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/abingham/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/abingham/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/abingham', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/abingham/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/abingham', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/abingham/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/79224?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/abingham/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/abingham/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/abingham/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'abingham', 'type': u'User', 'id': 79224, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/abingham/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20Documentation', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: Documentation'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Defect', 'color': u'444444', 'name': u'Defect'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Easy%20Fix', 'color': u'02e10c', 'name': u'Easy Fix'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/priority:%20normal', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'priority: normal'}]
body:
numpy.load() says that the `file` parameter must support seek() and read(). However, in the event that pickle.load() is invoked on the file (i.e. via the _cload() function), the file must also support readline(). According to the pickle documentation (and based on my actual experience), the pickle.load() requirements on the file-like object are:

  The file-like object must have two methods, a read() method
  that takes an integer argument, and a readline() method that
  requires no arguments.

So, it seems that the numpy.load() docstring should be updated to indicate this somehow.

title: save/load and tofile/fromfile fail silently for large arrays on Mac os X
body:
It seems that saving large numpy arrays to disk using numpy.save fails silently for very large matrices, example:

```python
In [5]: a = np.random.randn(500000000)

In [6]: 

In [6]: a
Out[6]: 
array([-1.00736353, -2.06696394,  1.46569636, ...,  0.89738222,
       -0.06982733,  0.06954417])

In [7]: np.save('a', a)

In [8]: b = np.load('a.npy')

In [9]: b
Out[9]: 
array([-1.00736353, -2.06696394,  1.46569636, ...,  0.        ,
        0.        ,  0.        ])
```
Note zeros in the end of the matrix that do not exist in a

I'm running numpy version 1.6.2:

```python
In [11]: np.version.version
Out[11]: '1.6.2'
````

on python 2.7.3 on Mac os X 10.8.2 if that helps

title: triu does not return boolean array when the input is boolean
body:
When tril is given a boolean array as an input it returns a boolean array as it supposed to.
However, triu returns an int array.


```
>>> from numpy import triu, tril, ones
>>> tril(ones((2,2),dtype=np.bool))
array([[ True, False],
       [ True,  True]], dtype=bool)
>>> triu(ones((2,2),dtype=np.bool))
array([[1, 1],
       [0, 1]])```

title: BUG: Fix regression for in1d with non-array input
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/seberg', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/61977?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'seberg', 'type': u'User', 'id': 61977, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/seberg/followers'}
body:
There was a regression introduced by the speed improvement in commit 6441c2a. This fixes it, and generally ravels the arrays for np.in1d. However it can be argued that at least the first array should
not be ravelled in the future.

Fixes "Issue gh-2755"

Since this seems to have been forgotten and it might be an annoying regression... @certik this should probably be in 1.7. to avoid a regression...

I used `np.asarray` here. In most places in `arraysetops` there is a call to `np.asanyarray` which probably should be replaced as well, since at least for matrices it fails? (Maybe `__array_wrap__` could be used, I am not sure if thats useful or not)

title: Make unique behave like sort when the argument is a list
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pchanial/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pchanial/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pchanial/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pchanial', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pchanial/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/pchanial', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pchanial/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/687271?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pchanial/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pchanial/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pchanial/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'pchanial', 'type': u'User', 'id': 687271, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/pchanial/followers'}
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20numpy.lib', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: numpy.lib'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Defect', 'color': u'444444', 'name': u'Defect'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/Easy%20Fix', 'color': u'02e10c', 'name': u'Easy Fix'}]
body:
The sort and unique functions do not handle lists in a consistent manner.

```python
>>> a = [complex(1,0), complex(1,-1), 1]
>>> np.sort(a)
array([ 1.-1.j,  1.+0.j,  1.+0.j]) # OK
>>> np.sort(np.array(a))
array([ 1.-1.j,  1.+0.j,  1.+0.j]) # OK
>>> np.unique(np.array(a))
array([ 1.-1.j,  1.+0.j ]) # OK
```
but
```python
>>> np.unique(a)
TypeError: no ordering relation is defined for complex numbers
```

title: ValueError: low level cast function is for unequal type numbers for object types
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/cgohlke', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/483428?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'cgohlke', 'type': u'User', 'id': 483428, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/cgohlke/followers'}
body:
This was reported on the [numpy-discussion mailing list](http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.comp.python.numeric.general/52285).

The following code using np.object_ data types works with numpy 1.5.1 but fails with 1.6.2. Other data types, np.float64 for example, seem to work.

```
In [1]: import numpy as np

In [2]: np.array(['a'], dtype='O').astype(('O', [('name', 'O')]))
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-3-f4a62241f13c> in <module>()
----> 1 np.array(['a'], dtype='O').astype(('O', [('name', 'O')]))

ValueError: low level cast function is for unequal type numbers

In [3]: np.array([16], dtype='d').astype(('d', [('name', 'd')]))
Out[3]: array([ 16.])
```

These downstream issues could be related:
* http://code.google.com/p/h5py/issues/detail?id=217
* https://github.com/CellProfiler/CellProfiler/issues/421

I'm not entirely sure the proposed patch is correct/best, but it seems to fix this and the h5py issue.

title: Polyfit fails for some complex values.
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mforbes/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mforbes/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mforbes/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mforbes', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mforbes/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/mforbes', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mforbes/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/1028433?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mforbes/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mforbes/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mforbes/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'mforbes', 'type': u'User', 'id': 1028433, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/mforbes/followers'}
body:
The following will fail with the current numpy:

```python
np.polyfit([1,1j], [1,1j], 1)
```

The problem is [line 557 of lib/polynomial.py](https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/af22fc43921e2e7f77e909a1acf77011f682ff7b/numpy/lib/polynomial.py#L577):

```python
    # scale lhs to improve condition number and solve
    scale = NX.sqrt((lhs*lhs).sum(axis=0))
    lhs /= scale
    c, resids, rank, s = lstsq(lhs, rhs, rcond) 
```
The two terms create a zero scale-factor here, making `lhs` infinite or nan, sending `lstsq` into never-never land.  (There is probably another bug in `lstsq` in that it should catch the invalid input and raise an error before charging ahead and consuming all the computer resources!)

It should probably be something like this (or maybe using `norm`)

```python
    # scale lhs to improve condition number and solve
    scale = NX.sqrt((abs(lhs)**2).sum(axis=0))
    lhs /= scale
    c, resids, rank, s = lstsq(lhs, rhs, rcond) 
```

With this modification, `polyfit` should work nicely with complex valued polynomials (assuming analyticity).  I will play with this for a bit to see if there are any other problems, then submit a PR.

title: np.unique: TypeError: requested sort not available for type
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bfroehle/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bfroehle/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bfroehle/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bfroehle', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bfroehle/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/bfroehle', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bfroehle/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/204333?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bfroehle/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bfroehle/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bfroehle/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'bfroehle', 'type': u'User', 'id': 204333, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bfroehle/followers'}
body:
Upon recently upgrading from 1.6.1 to 1.6.2, I discovered that the well-intentioned 74b9f5ee introduced a regression in `np.unqiue`:

```
>>> import numpy as np
>>> np.__version__
'1.6.2'
>>> 
>>> def unique_rows(A):
...     A = np.ascontiguousarray(A)
...     assert A.ndim == 2
...     B, I, J = np.unique(A.view([('', A.dtype)]*A.shape[1]), True, True)
...     return B.view(A.dtype).reshape((-1, A.shape[1]), order='C'), I, J
... 
>>> A = np.array([[1, 2], [1, 3], [1, 2]], dtype='i')
>>> 
>>> unique_rows(A)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "<stdin>", line 4, in unique_rows
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/numpy/lib/arraysetops.py", line 178, in unique
    perm = ar.argsort(kind='mergesort')
TypeError: requested sort not available for type
```

I filed a bug report against this yesterday (gh-2785) where I learned it was a known issue and has been fixed in 1.7.x.

While I realize a 1.6.3 release is unlikely, there's no harm in reverting this in the `maintenance/1.6.x` branch.  I've attached a pull request which does just that, and adds a regression test.

Of course this should _NOT_ be committed to 1.7.x or master, although the regression test could be cherry-picked onto that branch.

title: np.unique: TypeError: requested sort not available for type
user: {'following_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bfroehle/following{/other_user}', 'gists_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bfroehle/gists{/gist_id}', 'organizations_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bfroehle/orgs', 'url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bfroehle', 'events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bfroehle/events{/privacy}', 'html_url': u'https://github.com/bfroehle', 'subscriptions_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bfroehle/subscriptions', 'avatar_url': u'https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/u/204333?v=3', 'repos_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bfroehle/repos', 'received_events_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bfroehle/received_events', 'gravatar_id': u'', 'starred_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bfroehle/starred{/owner}{/repo}', 'site_admin': False, 'login': u'bfroehle', 'type': u'User', 'id': 204333, 'followers_url': u'https://api.github.com/users/bfroehle/followers'}
body:
Upon recently upgrading from 1.6.1 to 1.6.2, I discovered that the well-intentioned 74b9f5ee broke my usage of `np.unqiue`:

```
>>> import numpy as np
>>> np.__version__
'1.6.2'
>>> 
>>> def unique_rows(A):
...     A = np.ascontiguousarray(A)
...     assert A.ndim == 2
...     B, I, J = np.unique(A.view([('', A.dtype)]*A.shape[1]), True, True)
...     return B.view(A.dtype).reshape((-1, A.shape[1]), order='C'), I, J
... 
>>> A = np.array([[1, 2], [1, 3], [1, 2]], dtype='i')
>>> 
>>> unique_rows(A)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "<stdin>", line 4, in unique_rows
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/numpy/lib/arraysetops.py", line 178, in unique
    perm = ar.argsort(kind='mergesort')
TypeError: requested sort not available for type
```

Can I work-around this in some way, without creating my own copy of `np.unique`?  Also why can't mergesort work for this type?

title: Is change in behavior of ``ndindex`` intentional?
labels: [{'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/component:%20numpy.core', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'component: numpy.core'}, {'url': u'https://api.github.com/repos/numpy/numpy/labels/priority:%20high', 'color': u'ff0000', 'name': u'priority: high'}]
body:
It looks like the behavior for ``ndindex`` has changed since 1.6.2. For example, the following used to work:

```
In [8]: np.ndindex(*())
Out[8]: <numpy.lib.index_tricks.ndindex at 0x1058b3910>

In [9]: np.ndindex((1,2,3))
Out[9]: <numpy.lib.index_tricks.ndindex at 0x1058b3c90>
```

but now they fail:

```
In [4]: np.ndindex(*())
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
/Volumes/Raptor/<ipython-input-4-6cef0413cccb> in <module>()
----> 1 np.ndindex(*())

/Volumes/Raptor/Library/Python/2.7/lib/python/site-packages/numpy/lib/index_tricks.pyc in __init__(self, *shape)
    534     """
    535     def __init__(self, *shape):
--> 536         x = as_strided(_nx.zeros(1), shape=shape, strides=_nx.zeros_like(shape))
    537         self._it = _nx.nditer(x, flags=['multi_index'], order='C')
    538 

/Volumes/Raptor/Library/Python/2.7/lib/python/site-packages/numpy/lib/stride_tricks.pyc in as_strided(x, shape, strides)
     26     if strides is not None:
     27         interface['strides'] = tuple(strides)
---> 28     return np.asarray(DummyArray(interface, base=x))
     29 
     30 def broadcast_arrays(*args):

/Volumes/Raptor/Library/Python/2.7/lib/python/site-packages/numpy/core/numeric.pyc in asarray(a, dtype, order)
    322 
    323     """
--> 324     return array(a, dtype, copy=False, order=order)
    325 
    326 def asanyarray(a, dtype=None, order=None):

ValueError: __array_interface__ shape must be at least size 1

In [5]: np.ndindex((1,2,3))
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
/Volumes/Raptor/<ipython-input-5-c1735c2d52d3> in <module>()
----> 1 np.ndindex((1,2,3))

/Volumes/Raptor/Library/Python/2.7/lib/python/site-packages/numpy/lib/index_tricks.pyc in __init__(self, *shape)
    534     """
    535     def __init__(self, *shape):
--> 536         x = as_strided(_nx.zeros(1), shape=shape, strides=_nx.zeros_like(shape))
    537         self._it = _nx.nditer(x, flags=['multi_index'], order='C')
    538 

/Volumes/Raptor/Library/Python/2.7/lib/python/site-packages/numpy/lib/stride_tricks.pyc in as_strided(x, shape, strides)
     26     if strides is not None:
     27         interface['strides'] = tuple(strides)
---> 28     return np.asarray(DummyArray(interface, base=x))
     29 
     30 def broadcast_arrays(*args):

/Volumes/Raptor/Library/Python/2.7/lib/python/site-packages/numpy/core/numeric.pyc in asarray(a, dtype, order)
    322 
    323     """
--> 324     return array(a, dtype, copy=False, order=order)
    325 
    326 def asanyarray(a, dtype=None, order=None):

TypeError: an integer is required
```

so I just wanted to check that these changes were intentional? (I can easily update my code if needed).

title: API Make PyArray_DATA return void*
body:
PyArray_DATA is documented as returning void*. Changing it to return
char* breaks code such as (in C++)::

    float* my_floats = static_cast<float*>(PyArray_DATA(my_array));

PyArray_BYTES returns char*, but is otherwise the same function.

*

This was previously discussed here: https://github.com/numpy/numpy/commit/abf0489b69496af2c9e19f8bf41356fa511e5f1a
as it caused a compilation error in mahotas:
https://github.com/luispedro/mahotas/issues/26

My main argument is that http://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/c-api.array.html clearly states that PyArray_DATA returns ``void*`` and unless there is a strong reason against changing the public API, it should not change. In this case, there is even a perfect alternative for those who wish to have the ``char*``: ``PyArray_BYTES``.
